body:
This looks great.

~~As for the alternatives, I'm unsure if we want a way to set the metadata there. Seems like a sensible thing though. The difference is developer experience now with a smaller payload vs. the ability to use that metadata later.~~

To be clear, the metadata can be set, but the switch is on return-type, so with this PR as-is, you can:

1. `return data`, or
2. `return (data, metadata)`

which matches the single-mimetype formatters. I think this probably wasn't the right call originally, so we can either try to make a more future-proof API here (return the 'full' mime-bundle, rather than its constituent parts), or stay consistent with other APIs.
+1 on concept, will read and review more thoroughly later.
Awesome, thanks for working on this @minrk

> Alternative design: rather than single method returning the mimebundle itself, return mime-keyed mapping to callables, e.g.:

I though about this one as well, but I don't see any advantage. It might be even more complicated if you can easily share computation between representations.

Once merge, we should open an issue to make the user-facing-docs better.

I'm open to backport to 5.x as it's core to the repr protocol.

> I'm open to backport to 5.x as it's core to the repr protocol.

Thank you thank you thank you

> I think this probably wasn't the right call originally, so we can either try to make a more future-proof API here (return the 'full' mime-bundle, rather than its constituent parts), or stay consistent with other APIs.

What would the 'full mimebundle' return look like?

Another request: while we are doing this, I would love to introduce a
second repr mimebundle method for documentation. Right now our frontends
can render MIME bundles for docs, but IPython doesn't send them for docs.
There are two parts to getting this to work:

1. Having a method or way of computing the MIME bundle for the docs of an
object.
2. Triggering that in IPython with help requests (foo?) or an explicit
function (display_doc(obj))

Even having 1. would be useful even if we didn't hook it up to the foo?
syntax immediately - the display_doc function would be trivial to write.

> Another request: while we are doing this, I would love to introduce a
> second repr mimebundle method for documentation. Right now our frontends
> can render MIME bundles for docs, but IPython doesn't send them for docs.
> There are two parts to getting this to work:
> 

That's untrue. That was introduce in IPython 5.0, it's been disable by default because of bugs, and feedback was requested (to stabilize it). In particular the rendering on notebook side was way worse than plaintext. As this haven't changed the flag was not turned on by default in 6.0.

There is some discussion going on to do what you want (rich docs), having a function on each object to return mimebundle is the wrong way to do it, but that's should not be dis discussed on this issue.

Ahh, cool, missed that work. Do you have a link to an issue/PR?

Sorry laggy connection so minimal info:

https://github.com/ipython/ipython/pull/9551
And mostly in person discussion, and me messing with sphinx docutils for
the last couple of weeks.
I have rendering of docstring (including :math: directive and blocks as
unicode in the terminal)

I've hit the limitation that many docstrings have info that can't be
computed on the fly (matplotlib register directive in their conf.py).

So lots  of stuff and though about that we can talk at the dev meeting if
you want to but not here.

Or, merged to try it out in master. 

Opened #10502 to make better narrative docs, and then we can backport to 5.x

That does not seem to work if ou call `display_png` on a object that define `_repr_mimebundle_` with both latex and png.. 

```python
class Gaussian(object):
    """A simple object holding data sampled from a Gaussian distribution.
    """
    def __init__(self, mean=0.0, std=1, size=1000):
        self.data = np.random.normal(mean, std, size)
        self.mean = mean
        self.std = std
        self.size = size
        # For caching plots that may be expensive to compute
        self._png_data = None
        
    def _figure_data(self, format):
        fig, ax = plt.subplots()
        ax.hist(self.data, bins=50)
        ax.set_xlim(-10.0,10.0)
        data = print_figure(fig, format)
        # We MUST close the figure, otherwise IPython's display machinery
        # will pick it up and send it as output, resulting in a double display
        plt.close(fig)
        return data
        
    def _repr_mimebundle_(self):
        if self._png_data is None:
            self._png_data = self._figure_data('png')
        math = r'$\mathcal{N}(\mu=%.2g, \sigma=%.2g),\ N=%d$' % (self.mean,
                                                                 self.std, self.size)
        return {'image/png':self._png_data,
                'text/latex':math
                }

display_png(Gaussian()) ## Show the latex. 
```

I guess this one was meant for backport was it ?  I dont' think it has been backported. 

@meeseeksdev backport
